awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Open Player and Community Modeling as a Learning Tool
awd_abstract_narration:
An active research area in intelligent tutoring systems and game-based learning is personalized learning. In these environments, the computer analyzes learner behaviors in real time and builds individual models of critical aspects of learning (e.g., level of engagement, knowledge acquisition) to adapt the system. While these player models capture essential elements of a learner, the valuable information they contain is usually opaque and hidden from the learners. As a result, players of adaptive learning games do not know how the game categorizes them and why the game changes. This then affects their learning, especially when learning complex concepts. To address this, the project will investigate a novel approach to personalized learning environments by providing learners with a toolset, called Open Player and Community Model, which allows learners to see their actions, tactics, and strategies as well as those of others. A playback system with a labeling toolset will also be created to allow teachers and other learners to annotate patterns they see others use, which will shed light on strategies and mental models of solutions, errors, corrections, and misconceptions. 
    
The project will explore how students learn problem-solving with tools that allow them to reflect on their practices and on how others solved similar problems. The research will study two questions: First, how do people engage with user/player models when they are made transparent and used to reflect on learning? Second, how can designers create meaningful visualizations for learners and instructors to support reflection on user/player models and crowdsourced annotations of problem solving behavior? Tools to support collecting and visualizing open player and community models will be developed and made available to the public. Studies of the tools will be conducted to determine how they support learning in complex domains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, researchers targeted the development of personalized learning through intelligent and game-based systems. This is an active area in STEM education, as it has the potential to enhance the educational experience, address accessibility, and push for broader participation. In particular, this project built on a game called Parallel, developed to teach parallel programming, a very important and central concept in computing. In previous work, we found that students had difficulty thinking about computational execution in parallel rather than sequence, which is how students are usually taught programming. 

 

This three-year project resulted in several contributions. First, we developed a novel system that uses visualization, data science, machine learning, and artificial intelligence algorithms to build models revealing the problem-solving behaviors of different users. This work extends the current methods within learning analytics and open learner models to develop a new method to develop and represent process models. This new representation and student-facing visualization system can enable different types of learning for procedural activities, such as debugging or problem-solving. We call this system an Open Player and Community Model. 

 

Second, we conducted several interviews with parallel programming instructors and students. Then we used various design methods to develop student-facing visualizations that can reveal how one solved a problem and how others solved the same problem, thus revealing different strategies and thought processes. We tested this system with various students taking  parallel programming courses at UCSC and Drexel. 

Third, given our interest in using such process methods within the learning process, we leveraged theories of self-regulated learning to understand the impact of visualizations of others on students’ self-reflection and adaptation. This led to several publications and future work directions toward developing better prompts and systems using the current Open Player and Community Model to enhance self-regulated learning. 

 

We published 10 scientific papers in various venues, including the Computer-Human Interaction Conference, Foundations of Digital Games, CHIPlay, the Journal of Learning Analytics, and Frontiers in Psychology. We have also submitted two more publications, one to the Computer-Human Interaction Conference and another to the Symposium of Applied Computing, on the process of developing and evaluating the student-facing visualization systems we developed. We further presented the work at various venues and panels, including CIRCLS. 

 

In conclusion, this project resulted in a novel student-facing open visualization system exhibiting the process of problem-solving within a learning game. We presented the system and the game through various scientific venues. We also made our game and videos of the system available on a public website. We believe this work will result in many broader impacts on developing visualization models and systems to enhance the learning process.
